content: [Full time airmail service began in the U.S.](/wiki/United_States_airmail_service#Transcontinental_air_mail "United States airmail service") with a fleet of airplanes transporting the mail day and night. The time for sending mail between New York and San Francisco was decreased from 70 hours to a little less than 35 hours westward and around 32 hours eastward. Stops by the airplanes for mail transfer and relief of crew were made at established air stations along the fully-equipped [Transcontinental Airway System](/wiki/Transcontinental_Airway_System "Transcontinental Airway System") at [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"); [Bellefonte, Pennsylvania](/wiki/Bellefonte,_Pennsylvania "Bellefonte, Pennsylvania"); [Cleveland](/wiki/Cleveland "Cleveland") and [Bryan, Ohio](/wiki/Bryan,_Ohio "Bryan, Ohio"); [Chicago](/wiki/Chicago "Chicago"); [Iowa City](/wiki/Iowa_City "Iowa City"); [Omaha](/wiki/Omaha "Omaha") and [North Platte, Nebraska](/wiki/North_Platte,_Nebraska "North Platte, Nebraska"); [Cheyenne](/wiki/Cheyenne,_Wyoming "Cheyenne, Wyoming"), [Rawlins](/wiki/Rawlins,_Wyoming "Rawlins, Wyoming") and [Rock Springs, Wyoming](/wiki/Rock_Springs,_Wyoming "Rock Springs, Wyoming"); [Salt Lake City](/wiki/Salt_Lake_City "Salt Lake City"); [Elko](/wiki/Elko,_Nevada "Elko, Nevada") and [Reno](/wiki/Reno,_Nevada "Reno, Nevada"); and [San Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco").

Japan held a national day of protest of the United States' [Immigration Act](/wiki/1924_Immigration_Act "1924 Immigration Act") the day it went into effect. Mass prayer meetings were conducted at [Shinto shrines](/wiki/Shinto_shrine "Shinto shrine") all over the country and an unknown Japanese man cut down the American flag at the U.S. embassy in Tokyo. The Japanese government gave the United States a formal note of regret over the flag theft. The flag was recovered the next day The perpetrator was arrested on July 3 in [Osaka](/wiki/Osaka "Osaka") and explained that he wanted to do something "heroic" before he died for his country.
sources: "U.S. Embassy Flag Cut Down by Japanese". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. July 1, 1924. p. 1.
"Japan Regrets Theft of Flag of U.S. Embassy". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*: 5. July 2, 1924.
Matheson, Roderick (July 4, 1924). "Jail Japanese Youth Who Stole Embassy Flag". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 5.

content: At the [Democratic National Convention](/wiki/1924_Democratic_National_Convention "1924 Democratic National Convention"), [William Gibbs McAdoo](/wiki/William_Gibbs_McAdoo "William Gibbs McAdoo") lost ground in balloting as [Al Smith](/wiki/Al_Smith "Al Smith") and [John W. Davis](/wiki/John_W._Davis "John W. Davis") steadily gained.
sources: Henning, Arthur Sears (July 2, 1924). "Gov. Smith and Davis Gain in Later Voting". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 1.

content: [Portugal](/wiki/Portugal "Portugal")'s Prime Minister [Álvaro de Castro](/wiki/%C3%81lvaro_de_Castro "Álvaro de Castro") fought a sword [duel](/wiki/Duel "Duel") with Flight Captain [Teófilo José Ribeiro da Fonseca](https://pt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Te%C3%B3filo_Jos%C3%A9_Ribeiro_da_Fonseca "pt:Teófilo José Ribeiro da Fonseca") over a political dispute. Captain Ribiero was wounded in the arm.
sources: "Castro, Ex-Premier, in Duel". *[New York Evening Post](/wiki/New_York_Post "New York Post")*: 5. July 2, 1924.

content: Inventor [Guglielmo Marconi](/wiki/Guglielmo_Marconi "Guglielmo Marconi") addressed the [Royal Society of Arts](/wiki/Royal_Society_of_Arts "Royal Society of Arts") in London describing his new beam system of short-wave wireless transmission. Marconi said this system could transmit more words per day between distant countries than was possible before, and more economically as well, resulting in a general reduction in telegraphic rates.
sources: Steele, John (July 3, 1924). "Radio Beam Ray to Speed Work and Cut Rates". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 5.

content: Italian border patrollers shot and killed two [Serbian](/wiki/Serbia "Serbia") soldiers and wounded a civilian bystander at the Serbian boundary line.
sources: "Italian Border Patrol Kills 2 Serb Soldiers". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. July 4, 1924. p. 8.

content: [U.S. Secretary of Commerce](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_Commerce "United States Secretary of Commerce") [Herbert Hoover](/wiki/Herbert_Hoover "Herbert Hoover") submitted a paper before the World Power Conference in [Wembley](/wiki/Wembley "Wembley"), London urging America's power plants to be linked together to save energy.
sources: Steele, John (July 4, 1924). "Link Up Nation's Power Plants, Hoover Urges". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 7.

Nathan*](https://web.archive.org/web/20131031114827/http://infopedia.nl.sg/articles/SIP_490_2004-12-23.html), Singapore Infopedia, [National Library Board](/wiki/National_Library_Board "National Library Board"), archived from [the original](http://infopedia.nl.sg/articles/SIP_490_2004-12-23.html) on 31 October 2013

content: [Michael Barrington](/wiki/Michael_Barrington "Michael Barrington"), English television actor known for the situation comedy *[Porridge](/wiki/Porridge_(1974_TV_series) "Porridge (1974 TV series)")*; in [Twickenham](/wiki/Twickenham "Twickenham"), [London](/wiki/London "London") (d. 1988)
sources: "Michael Barrington". *[The Times](/wiki/The_Times "The Times")*. No. 63103. 9 June 1988. p. 16.

content: The [Caesar salad](/wiki/Caesar_salad "Caesar salad") was created in [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico") by Italian-born restaurateur [Caesar Cardini](/wiki/Caesar_Cardini "Caesar Cardini") at his restaurant in [Tijuana](/wiki/Tijuana "Tijuana"), [Caesar's](/wiki/Caesar%27s "Caesar's"). According to the Cardini family, Caesar had been unprepared for the large number of Americans crossing the border to legally purchase liquor at his eatery during the long Fourth of July weekend, and conserved his available supply of food by putting together the large salad in the middle of the dining room.

A new version of the [Progressive Party](/wiki/Progressive_Party_(United_States,_1924) "Progressive Party (United States, 1924)"), unrelated to the previous [organization nicknamed the "Bull Moose" Party](/wiki/Progressive_Party_(United_States,_1912%E2%80%931920) "Progressive Party (United States, 1912–1920)"), opened a convention in [Cleveland](/wiki/Cleveland "Cleveland") and nominated U.S. Senator [Robert M. La Follette](/wiki/Robert_M._La_Follette,_Sr. "Robert M. La Follette, Sr.") of [Wisconsin](/wiki/Wisconsin "Wisconsin") as a third-party candidate for U.S. president.
sources: "New Political Group Gathers for Convention". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. July 4, 1924. p. 1.

content: British tennis player [Kitty McKane Godfree](/wiki/Kitty_McKane_Godfree "Kitty McKane Godfree") defeated [Helen Wills](/wiki/Helen_Wills "Helen Wills") of the U.S. to win the [women's singles championship](/wiki/1924_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles "1924 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Singles") at the [Wimbledon](/wiki/1924_Wimbledon_Championships "1924 Wimbledon Championships").
sources: Steele, John (July 5, 1924). "Kitty Snatches Wimbledon Title from Our Helen". *Chicago Daily Tribune*. p. 10.

content: [Glacier National Park](/wiki/Glacier_National_Park_(U.S.) "Glacier National Park (U.S.)") concessions worker Donald T. Fly drowned in [Saint Mary Lake](/wiki/Saint_Mary_Lake "Saint Mary Lake").
sources: Minetor, Randi (2016). [*Death in Glacier National Park: Stories of Accidents and Foolhardiness in the Crown of the Continent*](https://books.google.com/books?id=ePKeCwAAQBAJ&q=Death+in+Glacier+National+Park). [Guilford, Connecticut](/wiki/Guilford,_Connecticut "Guilford, Connecticut"): [Lyons Press](/wiki/Lyons_Press "Lyons Press"). pp. 9–10. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [9781493025473](/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781493025473 "Special:BookSources/9781493025473").

content: Calvin Coolidge, Jr. was reported to be seriously ill.
sources: "Coolidge Son Gravely Ill of Poisoning". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. July 5, 1924. p. 1.

content: **Born:** [Eva Marie Saint](/wiki/Eva_Marie_Saint "Eva Marie Saint"), American actress; in [Newark, New Jersey](/wiki/Newark,_New_Jersey "Newark, New Jersey")

The official opening ceremonies for the [Summer Olympics](/wiki/1924_Summer_Olympics "1924 Summer Olympics") were conducted at [Colombes Stadium](/wiki/Stade_Olympique_Yves-du-Manoir "Stade Olympique Yves-du-Manoir") in Paris, France. Germany was absent for the second consecutive Olympics, having not been invited by the Organizing Committee.
sources: Wales, Henry (July 6, 1924). "30,000 Cheer as Olympic Games Formally Open". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. Part 2, p. 1.

Guttmann, Allen (1992). [*The Olympics: A History of the Modern Games*](https://archive.org/details/olympicshistoryo00gutt/page/38). Urbana and Chicago: University of Illinois Press. p. [38](https://archive.org/details/olympicshistoryo00gutt/page/38). [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [0-252-01701-3](/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-252-01701-3 "Special:BookSources/0-252-01701-3").

content: [Jean Borotra](/wiki/Jean_Borotra "Jean Borotra") defeated fellow Frenchman [René Lacoste](/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Lacoste "René Lacoste") in the [Men's Singles Final](/wiki/1924_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "1924 Wimbledon Championships – Men's Singles") at [Wimbledon](/wiki/1924_Wimbledon_Championships "1924 Wimbledon Championships").
sources: "Americans Win Two Titles in Tennis Finals at Wimbledon". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. July 6, 1924. p. Part 2 p. 1.

content: [Rebellion broke out](/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_Revolt_of_1924 "São Paulo Revolt of 1924") in the Brazilian city of [São Paulo](/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo "São Paulo") as a group of lieutenants and other junior Brazilian Army officers— the "tenentes"— sought to overthrow [President](/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_Brazil "List of presidents of Brazil") [Arthur Bernardes](/wiki/Arthur_Bernardes "Arthur Bernardes"). The revolt would last for 23 days, during which 1,000 people were killed and another 4,000 injured during the [bombardment of the city](/wiki/Bombing_of_S%C3%A3o_Paulo "Bombing of São Paulo") by troops loyal to the government.

**Born:**
	* [Niels Jannasch](/wiki/Niels_Jannasch "Niels Jannasch"), German-born Canadian historian; in [Holzminden](/wiki/Holzminden "Holzminden") (d. 2001)
	* [Osman Lins](/wiki/Osman_Lins "Osman Lins"), Brazilian fiction writer; in [Vitória de Santo Antão](/wiki/Vit%C3%B3ria_de_Santo_Ant%C3%A3o "Vitória de Santo Antão") (d. 1978)
	* [János Starker](/wiki/J%C3%A1nos_Starker "János Starker"), Hungarian cellist; in [Budapest](/wiki/Budapest "Budapest") (d. 2013)
[Niels Jannasch](/wiki/Niels_Jannasch "Niels Jannasch"), German-born Canadian historian; in [Holzminden](/wiki/Holzminden "Holzminden") (d. 2001)
[Osman Lins](/wiki/Osman_Lins "Osman Lins"), Brazilian fiction writer; in [Vitória de Santo Antão](/wiki/Vit%C3%B3ria_de_Santo_Ant%C3%A3o "Vitória de Santo Antão") (d. 1978)
[János Starker](/wiki/J%C3%A1nos_Starker "János Starker"), Hungarian cellist; in [Budapest](/wiki/Budapest "Budapest") (d. 2013)

At the Democratic National Convention, delegates divided between [Alfred E. Smith](/wiki/Alfred_E._Smith "Alfred E. Smith") (who had moved into the front after the 86th ballot) and former frontrunner [William G. McAdoo](/wiki/William_G._McAdoo "William G. McAdoo"). After a recess following the 93rd ballot, offered to take his name out of contention if McAdoo would do the same. Indiana U.S. Senator [Samuel M. Ralston](/wiki/Samuel_M._Ralston "Samuel M. Ralston") in third place, released his delegates, but McAdoo refused the Smith offer before it could be announced on the floor of the convention. On the 94th ballot, took the lead again with 395 over 364.5 for Smith, with John W. Davis moving into third place. Balloting continued past midnight until an adjournment at 4:00 a.m.

The [Communist International](/wiki/Communist_International "Communist International") in Moscow condemned the U.S. [Immigration Act](/wiki/Immigration_Act_of_1924 "Immigration Act of 1924") and passed a resolution advocating unrestricted worldwide immigration.
sources: Day, Donald (July 9, 1924). "Denounce U.S. Immigrant Law at Red Congress". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 7.

content: **Died:** [Walter R. Allman](/wiki/Walter_R._Allman "Walter R. Allman"), 40, American comic strip artist who wrote and drew *The Doings of the Duffs* from its launch in 1914 until 1923, when he suffered a nervous breakdown.
sources: ["Walter Allman, Creator of 'The Duffs,' is Dead"](https://www.newspapers.com/clip/46350385/walter-allman-creator-of-the-duffs/). *[Stockton Daily Evening Record](/wiki/Stockton_Daily_Evening_Record "Stockton Daily Evening Record")*. Cleveland. 1924-07-08. p. 6. Retrieved 2020-03-08 – via Newspapers.com.

content: The [World Energy Council](/wiki/World_Energy_Council "World Energy Council") was founded as the World Power Conference at a meeting of the same name in [London](/wiki/London "London"), where more than 1,700 experts from 40 nations gathered to discuss energy issues. [D. N. Dunlop](/wiki/Daniel_Nicol_Dunlop "Daniel Nicol Dunlop") of Scotland, who had organized the conference, was elected as the organization's first secretary-general.
sources: Wright, Rebecca; Shin, Hiroki; Trentmann, Frank (2013). [*From World Power Conference to World Energy Council: 90 Years of Energy Cooperation, 1923 - 2013*](http://www.worldenergy.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/A-Brief-History-of-the-World-Energy-Council.pdf) (PDF). World Energy Council. p. 13. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-0-946121-31-1](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-946121-31-1 "Special:BookSources/978-0-946121-31-1"). Retrieved 30 August 2017.
Grieves, Forest L. (1974). *International law, organization, and the environment*. University of Arizona Press. p. 41.

content:
**Born:**
	* [Brett Somers](/wiki/Brett_Somers "Brett Somers"), Canadian-born U.S. actress, singer and comedian; in [Saint John, New Brunswick](/wiki/Saint_John,_New_Brunswick "Saint John, New Brunswick") (d. 2007)
	* [Charlie Tully](/wiki/Charlie_Tully "Charlie Tully"), Northern Irish footballer; in [Belfast](/wiki/Belfast "Belfast") (d. 1971)

[Brett Somers](/wiki/Brett_Somers "Brett Somers"), Canadian-born U.S. actress, singer and comedian; in [Saint John, New Brunswick](/wiki/Saint_John,_New_Brunswick "Saint John, New Brunswick") (d. 2007)
[Charlie Tully](/wiki/Charlie_Tully "Charlie Tully"), Northern Irish footballer; in [Belfast](/wiki/Belfast "Belfast") (d. 1971)

**Died:** [J. B. van Heutsz](/wiki/J._B._van_Heutsz "J. B. van Heutsz"), Dutch military officer and former [Governor-general of the Dutch East Indies](/wiki/Governor-general_of_the_Dutch_East_Indies "Governor-general of the Dutch East Indies") (now Indonesia), known for bringing an end to the [Aceh War](/wiki/Aceh_War "Aceh War")

[Harold Osborn](/wiki/Harold_Osborn "Harold Osborn") of the U.S. won the [men's decathlon](/wiki/Athletics_at_the_1924_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_decathlon "Athletics at the 1924 Summer Olympics – Men's decathlon") at the Summer Olympics in [Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris"), finishing ahead of 35 other competitors. Osborn finish first in the 100m dash, the high jump, and the 110m hurdles, and in second place in the long jump and the pole vault.
sources: ["Athletics at the 1924 Paris Summer Games: Men's Decathlon"](https://web.archive.org/web/20200417175508/https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/summer/1924/ATH/mens-decathlon.html). *sports-reference.com*. Archived from [the original](https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/summer/1924/ATH/mens-decathlon.html) on 17 April 2020. Retrieved 24 January 2018.

content: [Paavo Nurmi](/wiki/Paavo_Nurmi "Paavo Nurmi") won the 10,000m cross-country race at the Olympics and then helped to win another gold medal for Finland in the team event. The races were held in blistering heat of 45 degrees Celsius; cross-country races were never an event at the Olympics again because of the number of runners collapsing from [heat exhaustion](/wiki/Heat_illness "Heat illness").
sources: Lennox, Doug (2009). [*Now You Know: Big Book of Sports*](https://archive.org/details/nowyouknowbigboo0000lenn_j6r9/page/232). Toronto: Magnetawan Communications, Inc. and Dundurn Press Ltd. pp. [232–233](https://archive.org/details/nowyouknowbigboo0000lenn_j6r9/page/232). [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-1-55488-454-4](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-55488-454-4 "Special:BookSources/978-1-55488-454-4").

content: Driving at 146.16 miles per hour (235.22 km/h) in his [Fiat Mephistopheles](/wiki/Fiat_Mephistopheles "Fiat Mephistopheles"), [Ernest Eldridge](/wiki/Ernest_Eldridge "Ernest Eldridge") of Great Britain broke the land speed record of 145.89 miles per hour (234.79 km/h) set earlier in the week (on Sunday, July 6) by [Rene Thomas](/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Thomas_(racing_driver) "René Thomas (racing driver)") of France. Both records had been set on a public road at [Arpajon](/wiki/Arpajon "Arpajon"), after which the [Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile](/wiki/F%C3%A9d%C3%A9ration_Internationale_de_l%27Automobile "Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile") announced that it would only recognize records set on closed racing circuits, bringing an end to attempts to set a land speed record on a roadway used by other motor vehicles.

The airmen attempting to be the first to [fly around the world](/wiki/First_aerial_circumnavigation "First aerial circumnavigation") landed in [Bucharest](/wiki/Bucharest "Bucharest") from [Constantinople](/wiki/Istanbul "Istanbul").
sources: Clayton, John (July 13, 1924). "Yankee Airmen in Bucharest". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 4.

content: The original trademark application for [Kleenex](/wiki/Kleenex "Kleenex") was filed by [Kimberly-Clark](/wiki/Kimberly-Clark "Kimberly-Clark") Corporation.
sources: ["Kleenex"](http://www.trademarkia.com/kleenex-71199932.html). *Trademarkia*. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: United States administration of the [Dominican Republic](/wiki/Dominican_Republic "Dominican Republic") ended as [Horacio Vásquez](/wiki/Horacio_V%C3%A1squez "Horacio Vásquez") was inaugurated as [President](/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_Dominican_Republic "List of presidents of the Dominican Republic"), succeeding the U.S.-selected provisional president [Juan Bautista Vicini Burgos](/wiki/Juan_Bautista_Vicini_Burgos "Juan Bautista Vicini Burgos") stepped aside.

The [Rex Ingram](/wiki/Rex_Ingram_(director) "Rex Ingram (director)")-directed film *[The Arab](/wiki/The_Arab_(1924_film) "The Arab (1924 film)")* opened at the [Capitol Theatre](/wiki/Capitol_Theatre_(New_York_City) "Capitol Theatre (New York City)") in New York City.
sources: Gmür, Leonhard (2013). *Rex Ingram: Hollywood's Rebel of the Silver Screen*. Berlin: epubli GmbH. p. 45. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-3-8442-4601-8](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-3-8442-4601-8 "Special:BookSources/978-3-8442-4601-8").

content: **Born:** [Carlo Bergonzi](/wiki/Carlo_Bergonzi_(tenor) "Carlo Bergonzi (tenor)"), Italian operatic tenor; in [Polesine](/wiki/Polesine "Polesine") (d. 2014)

**Died:** [M. Belle Brown](/wiki/M._Belle_Brown "M. Belle Brown"), M.D., 76, pioneering female U.S. surgeon and one of the few women during the 19th surgery to be trained to do surgery; she later became the dean of the [New York Medical College and Hospital for Women](/wiki/New_York_Medical_College_and_Hospital_for_Women "New York Medical College and Hospital for Women")
sources: Hover, John C. (1919). [*Memoirs of the Miami valley*](https://archive.org/details/memoirsofmiamiva03hove_0). Robert O. Law company. p. [44](https://archive.org/details/memoirsofmiamiva03hove_0/page/44). Retrieved 12 August 2017.

content: The short-lived [Tungus Republic](/wiki/Tungus_Republic "Tungus Republic") was proclaimed independent within the [Khabarovsk Krai](/wiki/Khabarovsk_Krai "Khabarovsk Krai") and part of the [Yakut Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic](/wiki/Yakut_Autonomous_Soviet_Socialist_Republic "Yakut Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic") of the Soviet Union in [Siberia](/wiki/Siberia "Siberia"). Rebels under the command of [Mikhail Artemyev](/wiki/Mikhail_Artemyev "Mikhail Artemyev") had seized the rural town of [Nelkan](/wiki/Nelkan "Nelkan") on May 10 and the port of [Ayan](/wiki/Ayan,_Russia "Ayan, Russia") on June 6. The Republic would surrender to the Soviet government on May 9, 1925.
sources: Pesterev, V.I. (1993), *Исторические миниатюры о Якутии* [*Historical miniatures about Yakutia*] (in Russian), p. 105

content: A reported 35 people died in [forest fires](/wiki/Forest_fire "Forest fire") in the U.S. states of [Washington](/wiki/Washington_(state) "Washington (state)"), [California](/wiki/California "California") and [Idaho](/wiki/Idaho "Idaho") and the Canadian province of [British Columbia](/wiki/British_Columbia "British Columbia").
sources: "Fires Sweep Pacific Coast". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. July 15, 1924. p. 1.

content: The premiere of the Harold Child opera *[Hugh the Drover](/wiki/Hugh_the_Drover "Hugh the Drover")* took place at [His Majesty's Theatre, London](/wiki/His_Majesty%27s_Theatre,_London "His Majesty's Theatre, London").

The aviators attempting to be the first to [fly around the world](/wiki/First_aerial_circumnavigation "First aerial circumnavigation") reached Paris, circling over the [Arc de Triomphe](/wiki/Arc_de_Triomphe "Arc de Triomphe").
sources: Wales, Henry (July 15, 1924). "Paris Cheers Yankee Flyers on World Trip". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 2.

content:
**Born:**
	* [Eva Marie Saint](/wiki/Eva_Marie_Saint "Eva Marie Saint"), American film and TV actress, 1954 Academy Award for *[On the Waterfront](/wiki/On_the_Waterfront "On the Waterfront")* and Primetime Emmy Award winner in 1990 for *People Like Us*; in [Newark, New Jersey](/wiki/Newark,_New_Jersey "Newark, New Jersey") in [Newark, New Jersey](/wiki/Newark,_New_Jersey "Newark, New Jersey"), to [Quaker](/wiki/Quakers "Quakers") parents. (alive in 2024)
	* [Libuše Domanínská](/wiki/Libu%C5%A1e_Doman%C3%ADnsk%C3%A1 "Libuše Domanínská"), Czech soprano opera singer; in [Brno](/wiki/Brno "Brno"), [Czechoslovakia](/wiki/Czechoslovakia "Czechoslovakia") (d.2021)
	* [Bill Lair](/wiki/James_William_Lair "James William Lair"), American military officer and CIA agent in CIA activities in Southeast Asia; in [Hilton, Oklahoma](/wiki/Hilton,_Oklahoma "Hilton, Oklahoma") (d.2014)
	* [Mal Johnson](/wiki/Mal_Johnson "Mal Johnson"), American journalist and the first black female White House correspondent; as Malvyn Houser in [Philadelphia](/wiki/Philadelphia "Philadelphia") (d.2007)
sources: ["Hollywood Star Walk"](https://projects.latimes.com/hollywood/star-walk/eva-marie-saint/index.html). *[LA Times](/wiki/LA_Times "LA Times")*. Retrieved April 22, 2022.

Shindler, Merrill (1990-05-13). ["Eva Marie Saint Finds TV Full of Contradictions"](https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-1990-05-13-9002090494-story.html). *Chicago Tribune*. Retrieved 2019-12-28.

content: [Eva Marie Saint](/wiki/Eva_Marie_Saint "Eva Marie Saint"), American film and TV actress, 1954 Academy Award for *[On the Waterfront](/wiki/On_the_Waterfront "On the Waterfront")* and Primetime Emmy Award winner in 1990 for *People Like Us*; in [Newark, New Jersey](/wiki/Newark,_New_Jersey "Newark, New Jersey") in [Newark, New Jersey](/wiki/Newark,_New_Jersey "Newark, New Jersey"), to [Quaker](/wiki/Quakers "Quakers") parents. (alive in 2024)
sources: ["Hollywood Star Walk"](https://projects.latimes.com/hollywood/star-walk/eva-marie-saint/index.html). *[LA Times](/wiki/LA_Times "LA Times")*. Retrieved April 22, 2022.

Shindler, Merrill (1990-05-13). ["Eva Marie Saint Finds TV Full of Contradictions"](https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-1990-05-13-9002090494-story.html). *Chicago Tribune*. Retrieved 2019-12-28.

content: [Libuše Domanínská](/wiki/Libu%C5%A1e_Doman%C3%ADnsk%C3%A1 "Libuše Domanínská"), Czech soprano opera singer; in [Brno](/wiki/Brno "Brno"), [Czechoslovakia](/wiki/Czechoslovakia "Czechoslovakia") (d.2021)

[Bill Lair](/wiki/James_William_Lair "James William Lair"), American military officer and CIA agent in CIA activities in Southeast Asia; in [Hilton, Oklahoma](/wiki/Hilton,_Oklahoma "Hilton, Oklahoma") (d.2014)

[Mal Johnson](/wiki/Mal_Johnson "Mal Johnson"), American journalist and the first black female White House correspondent; as Malvyn Houser in [Philadelphia](/wiki/Philadelphia "Philadelphia") (d.2007)

**Died:**
	* [Isabella Ford](/wiki/Isabella_Ford "Isabella Ford"), 69, English socialist, feminist, trade unionist and writer
	* [Alvey A. Adee](/wiki/Alvey_A._Adee "Alvey A. Adee"), 81, Deputy U.S. Secretary of States since 1886, died four days after his June 30 retirement.
[Isabella Ford](/wiki/Isabella_Ford "Isabella Ford"), 69, English socialist, feminist, trade unionist and writer
[Alvey A. Adee](/wiki/Alvey_A._Adee "Alvey A. Adee"), 81, Deputy U.S. Secretary of States since 1886, died four days after his June 30 retirement.

The British and Italian governments signed an agreement on the [Jubba River](/wiki/Jubba_River "Jubba River") in Africa as the British ceded their territory on the northern side; it became [Italian Trans-Juba](/wiki/Italian_Trans-Juba "Italian Trans-Juba").
sources: ["Chronology 1924"](http://www.indiana.edu/~league/1924.htm). *indiana.edu*. 2002. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: The first major nationwide news story in the U.S. about a tall, hairy "apeman" that walked upright, in the Pacific Northwest was published in *[The Oregonian](/wiki/The_Oregonian "The Oregonian")*, the largest circulation newspaper in [Portland, Oregon](/wiki/Portland,_Oregon "Portland, Oregon"), and then picked up by the Associated Press. In 1958, the mysterious creature would first be described as "[Bigfoot](/wiki/Bigfoot "Bigfoot")" because of the large footprints observed after a sighting in northern California.
sources: Flight, Tim (November 9, 2018). ["The Hairy History of Bigfoot in 20 Intriguing Events"](https://historycollection.com/the-hairy-history-of-bigfoot-in-20-intriguing-events/10/). *historycollection.com*. Retrieved April 13, 2021.

content: The London Reparations Conference opened to arrange for the implementation of the [Dawes Plan](/wiki/Dawes_Plan "Dawes Plan").
sources: ["Chronology 1924"](http://www.indiana.edu/~league/1924.htm). *indiana.edu*. 2002. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: The airmen trying to make the [first aerial circumnavigation of the globe](/wiki/First_aerial_circumnavigation "First aerial circumnavigation") flew from Paris to London.
sources: "Here's the Complete Log of the Flyers Round the World". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. September 16, 1924. p. 2.

content: [USS *Barracuda*](/wiki/USS_Barracuda_(SS-163) "USS Barracuda (SS-163)"), [submarine](/wiki/Submarine "Submarine") "twice as large as any built previously for the United States Navy", was launched from the [Portsmouth Naval Shipyard](/wiki/Portsmouth_Naval_Shipyard "Portsmouth Naval Shipyard") at [New Hampshire](/wiki/New_Hampshire "New Hampshire") as the first of the new generation of American subs, the [V-boats](/wiki/V-boat "V-boat").

Future Hall of Famer[Jesse Haines](/wiki/Jesse_Haines "Jesse Haines") pitched a [no-hitter](/wiki/No-hitter "No-hitter") for the [St. Louis Cardinals](/wiki/St._Louis_Cardinals "St. Louis Cardinals") in a 5–0 win over the [Boston Braves](/wiki/History_of_the_Boston_Braves "History of the Boston Braves").
sources: ["July 17, 1924 Boston Braves at St. Louis Cardinals"](https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/SLN/SLN192407170.shtml). *[Baseball-Reference.com](/wiki/Baseball-Reference.com "Baseball-Reference.com")*. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: **Died:** [Isabella Stewart Gardner](/wiki/Isabella_Stewart_Gardner "Isabella Stewart Gardner"), 84, American art collector and philanthropist

U.S. Vice Consul to Iran Robert Imbrie was beaten to death by an angry mob in [Tehran](/wiki/Tehran "Tehran") after he photographed a gathering at a sacred watering place where a miracle was said to have taken place. Police were slow to help because they were intimidated by the soldiers of the Cossack Brigade, the real authority in Iran, who were participating in the attack. Imbrie's companion [Allen Dulles](/wiki/Allen_Dulles "Allen Dulles") survived the beating.
sources: Basil, H. (July 19, 1924). "U.S. Consul Slain in Persia". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 1.

Zirinsky, Michael (1986). ["Blood, Power and Hypocrisy: The Murder of Robert Imbrie and American Relations with Pahlavi Iran, 1924"](http://scholarworks.boisestate.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1000&context=history_facpubs). [Boise State University](/wiki/Boise_State_University "Boise State University"). Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: The [Napalpí massacre](/wiki/Napalp%C3%AD_massacre "Napalpí massacre") occurred in [Argentina](/wiki/Argentina "Argentina") when 400 indigenous [Toba people](/wiki/Toba_people "Toba people") were killed by Argentine police and ranchers.
sources: Carlos Salamanca (2008). ["De las fosas al panteón: contrasentidos en las honras de los indios revividos"](https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/287295953.pdf) (PDF). *core.ac.uk*. Revista Colombiana de Antropología. pp. 7–39. Retrieved 14 January 2021.

["Un 'procès de la vérité' en Argentine, 98 ans après le massacre de Napalpí visant des populations indigènes"](https://www.newsendip.com/fr/un-proces-de-la-verite-en-argentine-98-ans-apres-le-massacre-de-napalpi-de-populations-indigenes-tabo-qom-mocovi/). 24 April 2022.

content: [Montana](/wiki/Montana "Montana") Senator [Burton K. Wheeler](/wiki/Burton_K._Wheeler "Burton K. Wheeler") was announced as the vice presidential nominee of the [Progressive Party](/wiki/Progressive_Party_(United_States,_1924%E2%80%9334) "Progressive Party (United States, 1924–34)") and running mate of presidential nominee [Robert M. La Follette](/wiki/Robert_M._La_Follette,_Sr. "Robert M. La Follette, Sr.").
sources: "Wheeler Joins La Follette; to War on Dawes". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. July 20, 1924. p. 1.

content: Pitcher [Herman "Hi" Bell](/wiki/Hi_Bell "Hi Bell") of the [St. Louis Cardinals](/wiki/1924_St._Louis_Cardinals_season "1924 St. Louis Cardinals season") started and finished a doubleheader baseball game, pitching all 9 innings of a 6 to 1 win over the [Boston Braves](/wiki/1924_Boston_Braves_season "1924 Boston Braves season") and all 9 innings of the second game of the day, a 2 to 1 win. Bell was the last Major League Baseball pitcher to pitch all 18 innings of two games on the same day.

**Born:**
	* [Petras Griškevičius](/wiki/Petras_Gri%C5%A1kevi%C4%8Dius "Petras Griškevičius"), Lithuanian Soviet leader who served as the *de facto* ruler of the [Lithuanian SSR](/wiki/Lithuanian_SSR "Lithuanian SSR") as General Secretary of the [Lithuanian Communist Party](/wiki/Lithuanian_Communist_Party "Lithuanian Communist Party") from 1974 until his death; in [Kriaunos](https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kriaunos "lt:Kriaunos") (d.1987)
	* [Stanley K. Hathaway](/wiki/Stanley_K._Hathaway "Stanley K. Hathaway"), U.S. Secretary of the Interior in 1975, Governor of Wyoming, 1967 to 1975; in [Osceola, Nebraska](/wiki/Osceola,_Nebraska "Osceola, Nebraska") (d. 2005)
	* [Pat Hingle](/wiki/Pat_Hingle "Pat Hingle"), American [character actor](/wiki/Character_actor "Character actor") on stage, film and TV; in [Miami](/wiki/Miami "Miami") (d. 2009)

[Petras Griškevičius](/wiki/Petras_Gri%C5%A1kevi%C4%8Dius "Petras Griškevičius"), Lithuanian Soviet leader who served as the *de facto* ruler of the [Lithuanian SSR](/wiki/Lithuanian_SSR "Lithuanian SSR") as General Secretary of the [Lithuanian Communist Party](/wiki/Lithuanian_Communist_Party "Lithuanian Communist Party") from 1974 until his death; in [Kriaunos](https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kriaunos "lt:Kriaunos") (d.1987)

[Stanley K. Hathaway](/wiki/Stanley_K._Hathaway "Stanley K. Hathaway"), U.S. Secretary of the Interior in 1975, Governor of Wyoming, 1967 to 1975; in [Osceola, Nebraska](/wiki/Osceola,_Nebraska "Osceola, Nebraska") (d. 2005)
[Pat Hingle](/wiki/Pat_Hingle "Pat Hingle"), American [character actor](/wiki/Character_actor "Character actor") on stage, film and TV; in [Miami](/wiki/Miami "Miami") (d. 2009)

**Died:** [Kingsley Fairbridge](/wiki/Kingsley_Fairbridge "Kingsley Fairbridge"), 39, British educator and founder of the Society for the Furtherance of Child Emigration to the Colonies (later the Fairbridge Society) died of complications after minor surgery for removal of a lymphatic tumor
[Tehran](/wiki/Tehran "Tehran") was placed under [martial law](/wiki/Martial_law "Martial law") due to high tensions over the death of Robert Imbrie.
sources: Basil, H. (July 21, 1924). "Martial Law in Tehran; Due to Murder of Yank". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 4.

content: [Ottavio Bottecchia](/wiki/Ottavio_Bottecchia "Ottavio Bottecchia") of Italy won the [Tour de France](/wiki/1924_Tour_de_France "1924 Tour de France").
[FIDE](/wiki/FIDE "FIDE") (*Fédération Internationale des Échecs*), the International Chess Federation that would oversee championship competition, was founded in Paris.
The Soviet sports newspaper *[Sovetsky Sport](/wiki/Sovetsky_Sport "Sovetsky Sport")* was founded.
**Born:** [Tatyana Lioznova](/wiki/Tatyana_Lioznova "Tatyana Lioznova"), Soviet Russian film director; in [Moscow](/wiki/Moscow "Moscow") (d. 2011)

"'[The Pageant of Empire: An Historical Epic](/wiki/Pageant_of_Empire#The_London_1924_Pageant_of_Empire "Pageant of Empire")"' began at [Empire Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium_(1923) "Wembley Stadium (1923)") in [Wembley, London](/wiki/Wembley,_London "Wembley, London") as the highlight of the [British Empire Exhibition](/wiki/British_Empire_Exhibition "British Empire Exhibition"). Directed by [Frank Lascelles](/wiki/Frank_Lascelles_(pageant_master) "Frank Lascelles (pageant master)"), the [pageant](/wiki/Medieval_pageant#20th_century_revival "Medieval pageant") featured 15,000 people, 300 horses, 500 donkeys, 730 camels, 72 monkeys, 1,000 doves, seven elephants, three bears and one macaw, and featured musical tributes to events in British history and to different countries of the Empire. The presentation would last three days before closing on July 13.

The [Leopold and Loeb](/wiki/Leopold_and_Loeb "Leopold and Loeb") trial began as defense lawyer [Clarence Darrow](/wiki/Clarence_Darrow "Clarence Darrow") told the [Illinois](/wiki/Illinois "Illinois") court that his clients were entering pleas of guilty.
sources: Forbes, Genevieve (July 22, 1924). "Young Killers Plead Guilty; Ask for Mercy". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 1.

Hannon, Michael (May 2010). ["Leopold and Loeb Case (1924)"](https://web.archive.org/web/20140923171802/http://darrow.law.umn.edu/trialpdfs/LEOPOLD_LOEB.pdf) (PDF). *University of Minnesota Law Library*. Archived from [the original](http://darrow.law.umn.edu/trialpdfs/LEOPOLD_LOEB.pdf) (PDF) on September 23, 2014. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: The Ponce-Castro Oyanguren Protocol was signed in [Ecuador](/wiki/Ecuador "Ecuador") between Ecuador's [Foreign Minister Nicolas Clemente Ponce](/wiki/List_of_ministers_of_foreign_affairs_of_Ecuador#Ministers "List of ministers of foreign affairs of Ecuador") and [Peruvian Ambassador](/wiki/List_of_ambassadors_of_Peru_to_Ecuador#List_of_representatives "List of ambassadors of Peru to Ecuador") [Enrique Castro Oyanguren](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enrique_Castro_Oyanguren "es:Enrique Castro Oyanguren") to resolve a border dispute between the two South American nations.

[Paris Olympics](/wiki/1924_Summer_Olympics "1924 Summer Olympics") organizer [Pierre de Coubertin](/wiki/Pierre_de_Coubertin "Pierre de Coubertin") lashed back at criticism of the games, calling the Paris press guilty of "magnifying the unpleasant incidents instead of fulfilling its duty and educating the people to a big sport ideal." He also said it was "idiotic" of the French government to build [Colombes Stadium](/wiki/Stade_Olympique_Yves-du-Manoir "Stade Olympique Yves-du-Manoir") so far outside of Paris without the proper transportation facilities. Some of the unfortunate incidents referred to included the French booing of the American flag at a rugby match and complaints over accommodations in the tennis tournament.
sources: Skene, Don (July 23, 1924). "France Enraged Over Slurs on Olympics". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 13.

content: Japan passed an amendment to its Nationality Law so that Japanese children born in the United States and other *jus soli* countries would automatically lose their Japanese nationality unless it was expressly retained within 14 days of birth. The amendment also allowed [dual citizens](/wiki/Multiple_citizenship "Multiple citizenship") in those countries to easily renounce their Japanese citizenship.
sources: Murazumi, Mie (2000). ["Japan's Laws on Dual Nationality in the Context of a Globalized World"](https://digital.lib.washington.edu/dspace-law/bitstream/handle/1773.1/813/9PacRimLPolyJ415.pdf?sequence=1) (PDF). University of Washington. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: **Died:** [Albert Bruce-Joy](/wiki/Albert_Bruce-Joy "Albert Bruce-Joy"), 81, Irish sculptor

After Norway's parliament, the [Storting](/wiki/Storting "Storting"), rejected a government plan for banning alcohol sale, [Prime Minister](/wiki/List_of_prime_ministers_of_Norway "List of prime ministers of Norway") [Abraham Berge](/wiki/Abraham_Berge "Abraham Berge") of [Norway](/wiki/Norway "Norway") and [his entire cabinet](/wiki/Berge%27s_Cabinet "Berge's Cabinet") announced their resignations. They would be replaced two days later.
sources: ["Abraham Berges regjering (Abraham Berge's Cabinet"](https://www.regjeringen.no/no/om-regjeringa/tidligere-regjeringer-og-historie/sok-i-regjeringer-siden-1814/historiske-regjeringer/regjeringsliste-1905-1945/abraham-berges-regjering-1923-1924/id507317/?expand=factboxRegjeringsmedlemmer) (in Norwegian). 27 May 2020. Retrieved 27 May 2020.

content: Twenty children were trampled to death and 17 injured as patrons fled a movie house in [Veracruz](/wiki/Veracruz_(city) "Veracruz (city)"), [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico") when the film caught fire.
sources: "20 Children Die, 17 Injured in Panic at Movie". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. July 24, 1924. p. 1.

content: The collapse of seats in a storm injured 20 people at a minor league baseball game in [Newton, Kansas](/wiki/Newton,_Kansas "Newton, Kansas").

The first [official flag of the U.S. state of Washington](/wiki/Flag_of_Washington "Flag of Washington") was unveiled at the office of the Washington Secretary of State at [Olympia](/wiki/Olympia,_Washington "Olympia, Washington").

The judge in the [Leopold and Loeb](/wiki/Leopold_and_Loeb "Leopold and Loeb") case fully explained to the defendants the consequences of pleading guilty and asked them to confirm their plea, which they did. The trial now became a question of whether or not the killers would receive the [death penalty](/wiki/Capital_punishment "Capital punishment").
sources: Hannon, Michael (May 2010). ["Leopold and Loeb Case (1924)"](https://web.archive.org/web/20140923171802/http://darrow.law.umn.edu/trialpdfs/LEOPOLD_LOEB.pdf) (PDF). *University of Minnesota Law Library*. Archived from [the original](http://darrow.law.umn.edu/trialpdfs/LEOPOLD_LOEB.pdf) (PDF) on September 23, 2014. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: **Died:** [Frank Frost Abbott](/wiki/Frank_Frost_Abbott "Frank Frost Abbott"), 84, American classical scholar

[Themistoklis Sofoulis](/wiki/Themistoklis_Sofoulis "Themistoklis Sofoulis") took office as the new [Prime Minister of Greece](/wiki/List_of_prime_ministers_of_Greece "List of prime ministers of Greece"), as [Alexandros Papanastasiou](/wiki/Alexandros_Papanastasiou "Alexandros Papanastasiou") stepped down.Sofoulis would serve less than three months, stepping down on November 27.
sources: Lentz, Harris M. (2014). [*Heads of States and Governments Since 1945*](https://books.google.com/books?id=RwfKAgAAQBAJ&pg=RA1-PA1901). Routledge. p. 1901. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-1-134-26497-1](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-134-26497-1 "Special:BookSources/978-1-134-26497-1").

content: World light heavyweight boxing champion [Gene Tunney](/wiki/Gene_Tunney "Gene Tunney") defeated [Georges Carpentier](/wiki/Georges_Carpentier "Georges Carpentier") by technical knockout at the beginning of the fifteenth round at the [Polo Grounds](/wiki/Polo_Grounds "Polo Grounds") in [New York](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City").
sources: Newman, Harry (July 25, 1924). "Tunney Stops Carpentier Amid Riot in 15th Round". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 19.

content: **Died:** [Palmer Cox](/wiki/Palmer_Cox "Palmer Cox"), 84, Canadian illustrator and author

The new issue of *[Workers' Weekly](/wiki/Workers%27_Weekly_(UK) "Workers' Weekly (UK)")*, the newspaper of the [Communist Party of Great Britain](/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Great_Britain "Communist Party of Great Britain"), included a provocative article entitled "An Open Letter to the Fighting Forces" which included passages such as, "Neither in a class war nor in a military war, will you turn your guns on your fellow workers", and, "Turn your weapons on your oppressors." The question of whether to charge editor [John Ross Campbell](/wiki/John_Ross_Campbell "John Ross Campbell") with incitement to [mutiny](/wiki/Mutiny "Mutiny") became a controversial issue known as the [Campbell Case](/wiki/Campbell_Case "Campbell Case").
sources: [Klugmann, James](/wiki/James_Klugmann "James Klugmann") (1968). *History of the Communist Party of Great Britain*. Vol. One: Formation and Early Years, 1919–1924. London: Lawrence and Wishart. pp. 366–367.

Dobson, Jeremy (2009). *Why Do the People Hate Me So?: The Strange Interlude Between the Two Great Wars in the Britain of Stanley Baldwin*. Leicester: Troubador Publishing Ltd. p. 102. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-1-84876-239-8](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-84876-239-8 "Special:BookSources/978-1-84876-239-8").

content: Greece announced it was expelling 50,000 [Armenians](/wiki/Armenians "Armenians") from the country.
sources: Mercer, Derrik (1989). *Chronicle of the 20th Century*. London: Chronicle Communications Ltd. p. 320. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-0-582-03919-3](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-582-03919-3 "Special:BookSources/978-0-582-03919-3").

content: [American League](/wiki/American_League "American League") president [Ban Johnson](/wiki/Ban_Johnson "Ban Johnson") ordered umpires to speed up baseball games by cutting short trivial arguments about balls and strikes as well as preventing players from taking too much time inspecting balls on suspicion they had been tampered with.
sources: "Ban Orders A.L. Umps to Speed Up Ball Games". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. July 26, 1924. p. 8.

content: **Born:** [Frank Church](/wiki/Frank_Church "Frank Church"), U.S. Senator for Idaho; in [Boise, Idaho](/wiki/Boise,_Idaho "Boise, Idaho") (d. 1984)
sources: ["CHURCH, Frank Forrester 1924 – 1984"](https://bioguide.congress.gov/search/bio/C000388). *[Biographical Directory of the United States Congress](/wiki/Biographical_Directory_of_the_United_States_Congress "Biographical Directory of the United States Congress")*. Retrieved 14 November 2023.

content: **Died:** [Azem Galica](/wiki/Azem_Galica "Azem Galica"), 34, Albanian nationalist and rebel who fought for the unification of Kosovo with Albania, died of wounds sustained in fighting soldiers of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia, bringing about the collapse of the ethnic Albanian rebellion.
sources: [Elsie, Robert](/wiki/Robert_Elsie "Robert Elsie") (2004). ["GALICA, AZEM (1889-1924.07.25)"](https://books.google.com/books?id=Fnbw1wsacSAC&q=Azem+galica&pg=PA63). *Historical Dictionary of Kosova*. Scarecrow Press. p. 63. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [0-8108-5309-4](/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-8108-5309-4 "Special:BookSources/0-8108-5309-4"). Retrieved 13 December 2023 – via Google Books.

content: Argentine pilot [Pedro Zanni](/wiki/Pedro_Zanni "Pedro Zanni") and mechanic Felipe Beltrame began their attempt to fly around the world, departing [Amsterdam](/wiki/Amsterdam "Amsterdam") in a Fokker C-IV biplane named *Ciudad de Buenos Aires*. With stops in [Baghdad](/wiki/Baghdad "Baghdad") and [Hanoi](/wiki/Hanoi "Hanoi"), [Hong Kong](/wiki/Hong_Kong "Hong Kong"), [Fuzhou](/wiki/Fuzhou "Fuzhou") and [Shanghai](/wiki/Shanghai "Shanghai"), and a change of planes after the first one was destroyed the two would get as far as [Tokyo](/wiki/Tokyo "Tokyo") before abandoning the trip on October 11, upon discovering that a British and American team had completed the [first aerial circumnavigation](/wiki/First_aerial_circumnavigation "First aerial circumnavigation") on September 28.

Boxer [Larry Estridge](/wiki/Larry_Estridge "Larry Estridge") of the British West Indies became the last person to win the [World Colored Middleweight Championship](/wiki/World_Colored_Middleweight_Championship "World Colored Middleweight Championship"), after defeating title holder [Panama Joe Gans](/wiki/Panama_Joe_Gans "Panama Joe Gans") in a 10-round bout at [Yankee Stadium](/wiki/Yankee_Stadium "Yankee Stadium"). Afterward, separate titles for African-American and white boxers would be abandoned.
sources: ["Larry Estridge"](http://boxrec.com/list_bouts.php?human_id=41735&cat=boxer). BoxRec. Retrieved 28 May 2012.

content: The [Ku Klux Klan](/wiki/Ku_Klux_Klan "Ku Klux Klan") staged a huge rally in [Issaquah, Washington](/wiki/Issaquah,_Washington "Issaquah, Washington"), drawing at least 13,000 people.
sources: Wilma, David (September 22, 1999). ["Ku Klux Klan stages huge rally in Issaquah on July 26, 1924"](http://www.historylink.org/_content/bart/index.cfm?DisplayPage=output.cfm&file_id=1682). *Historylink*. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content:
**Born:**
	* [Dirk de Villiers](/wiki/Dirk_de_Villiers "Dirk de Villiers"), South African filmmaker; in [Douglas, Northern Cape](/wiki/Douglas,_Northern_Cape "Douglas, Northern Cape") (d. 2009)
	* [Saville Sax](/wiki/Saville_Sax "Saville Sax"), American drifter who assisted the espionage activities of his friend, [Theodore Hall](/wiki/Theodore_Hall "Theodore Hall") by delivering classified nuclear secrets to Soviet spies; in [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") (d.1980). Although their access to materials was blocked, the two were never charged or prosecuted out of concern that the Soviets would learn that U.S. cryptanalysts were decoding Soviet cables.
sources: ["Dirk de Villiers: Director, Actor, Producer"](https://mubi.com/cast/dirk-de-villiers). MUBI. Retrieved 14 October 2020.

content: [Dirk de Villiers](/wiki/Dirk_de_Villiers "Dirk de Villiers"), South African filmmaker; in [Douglas, Northern Cape](/wiki/Douglas,_Northern_Cape "Douglas, Northern Cape") (d. 2009)
sources: ["Dirk de Villiers: Director, Actor, Producer"](https://mubi.com/cast/dirk-de-villiers). MUBI. Retrieved 14 October 2020.

content: [Saville Sax](/wiki/Saville_Sax "Saville Sax"), American drifter who assisted the espionage activities of his friend, [Theodore Hall](/wiki/Theodore_Hall "Theodore Hall") by delivering classified nuclear secrets to Soviet spies; in [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") (d.1980). Although their access to materials was blocked, the two were never charged or prosecuted out of concern that the Soviets would learn that U.S. cryptanalysts were decoding Soviet cables.
**Died:** [Manuel Araullo](/wiki/Manuel_Araullo "Manuel Araullo"), 71, [Chief Justice of the Philippines](/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_the_Philippines "Chief Justice of the Philippines") since 1921
sources: ["Chief Justice Manuel G. Araullo"](https://elibrary.judiciary.gov.ph/supremecourtjustices/chiefjustice/4). *Supreme Court E-Library*. Retrieved November 2, 2023.

content: The closing ceremonies of the [Summer Olympics](/wiki/1924_Summer_Olympics "1924 Summer Olympics") were conducted at [Colombes Stadium](/wiki/Stade_Olympique_Yves-du-Manoir "Stade Olympique Yves-du-Manoir") in Paris. The United States led the [final medal count](/wiki/1924_Summer_Olympics_medal_table "1924 Summer Olympics medal table") with 45 gold medals.
sources: "Yanks Get Lion's Share of Prizes as Olympic Games End". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. July 28, 1924. p. 13.

content: Lieutnant Doxakis, a Greek Army officer in charge of enforcing martial law in the [Kato Nevrokopi](/wiki/Kato_Nevrokopi "Kato Nevrokopi") region on the border of Bulgaria, [carried out the massacre of 17 Bulgarian](/wiki/Tarlis_incident "Tarlis incident") peasants arrested in the village of [Tarlis](https://el.wikipedia.org/wiki/%CE%92%CE%B1%CE%B8%CF%8D%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%80%CE%BF%CF%82_%CE%94%CF%81%CE%AC%CE%BC%CE%B1%CF%82Tarlis "el:Βαθύτοπος ΔράμαςTarlis") (now Vathytopos), near the Greco-Bulgarian border. Lieutenant Doxakis told his commander that their 10-soldier unit had come under attack from Bulgarian guerrillas and that they were forced to kill the prisoners who were attempting to escape.
sources: ["Review of Chairs of History at Law and History Faculty of South-West University - Blagoevgrad, vol. 1/2003, p. 8"](https://web.archive.org/web/20111007014750/http://www.history.swu.bg/PDF/19.pdf) (PDF). Archived from [the original](http://www.history.swu.bg/PDF/19.pdf) (PDF) on 2011-10-07. Retrieved 2008-12-06.

content: The first Stånga Games, were held on the Swedish island of [Gotland](/wiki/Gotland "Gotland") as an annual competition of traditional Swedish Gothic sports, including [paerk](/wiki/P%C3%A4rk "Pärk"), a team game similar to a cross between baseball and football; [varpa](/wiki/Varpa "Varpa"), similar to horseshoe pitching; *Herre på stång* (a fight between two men on a pole) and three variations of [tug of war](/wiki/Tug_of_war "Tug of war").

**Born:**
	* [Anthony Acevedo](/wiki/Anthony_Acevedo "Anthony Acevedo"), Mexican-American U.S. Army medic who documented his incarceration as a prisoner of war in [Berga concentration camp](/wiki/Berga_concentration_camp "Berga concentration camp") in Germany and gave first-hand accounts of the treatment of Jews in the Nazi death camps; in [San Bernardino, California](/wiki/San_Bernardino,_California "San Bernardino, California") (d. 2018)
	* [Mohsen Vaziri-Moghaddam](/wiki/Mohsen_Vaziri-Moghaddam "Mohsen Vaziri-Moghaddam") Iranian abstract expressionist painter and sculptor; in [Tehran](/wiki/Tehran "Tehran")
sources: Sandomir, Richard (March 16, 2018). ["Anthony Acevedo, Who Documented His Holocaust Ordeal, Dies at 93"](https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/16/obituaries/anthony-acevedo-who-documented-his-holocaust-ordeal-dies-at-93.html). *The New York Times*. Retrieved March 19, 2018.

**Died:** [Ferruccio Busoni](/wiki/Ferruccio_Busoni "Ferruccio Busoni"), 58, Italian pianist and composer

The secret "[May Manifesto](/wiki/May_Manifesto "May Manifesto")" of the [Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organisation](/wiki/Internal_Macedonian_Revolutionary_Organisation "Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organisation") (IMRO) was published after IMRO leader [Todor Aleksandrov](/wiki/Todor_Aleksandrov "Todor Aleksandrov") refused to cooperate with the Soviet Union's wishes for IMRO to join [Comintern](/wiki/Comintern "Comintern"). Despite Alexandrov's claims that the publication was a forgery, he would be assassinated the following month.

The [revolt by Brazilian Army officers](/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_Revolt_of_1924 "São Paulo Revolt of 1924") in [São Paulo](/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo "São Paulo") ended after the rebels quietly withdrew to [Campinas](/wiki/Campinas "Campinas"). By the time that the government realized that the rebels had quit, the last rebels had been gone from the city for five hours. The city was recaptured by the government, at a cost of more than 500 deaths and almost 5,000 injuries. Sao Paulo state governor [Carlos de Campos](/wiki/Carlos_de_Campos "Carlos de Campos"), who had fled the city on July 8, returned to his office later in the day.

[Ljubomir Davidović](/wiki/Ljubomir_Davidovi%C4%87 "Ljubomir Davidović") became [Prime Minister of Yugoslavia](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Yugoslavia "Prime Minister of Yugoslavia") after [Nikola Pašić](/wiki/Nikola_Pa%C5%A1i%C4%87 "Nikola Pašić") resigned.

**Born:**
	* [Anne Braden](/wiki/Anne_Braden "Anne Braden"), American civil rights activist; in [Louisville, Kentucky](/wiki/Louisville,_Kentucky "Louisville, Kentucky") (d. 2006)
	* [Vishwanath N. Nadkarni](/wiki/Vishwanath_N._Nadkarni "Vishwanath N. Nadkarni"), Indian financier and Chairman of the State Bank of India,1983 to 1984 (d.2016)

The practicality of [airmail](/wiki/Airmail "Airmail") was demonstrated for the public when the U.S. Army air service carried a cargo of mail from [Nashville, Tennessee](/wiki/Nashville,_Tennessee "Nashville, Tennessee") to [Chicago](/wiki/Chicago "Chicago") in 2 hours and 29 minutes.
sources: "Nashville Puts Chicago to Air Mail to Test". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. July 30, 1924. p. 10.

content: Germany and the Soviet Union signed a trade agreement which ended the two-month standoff over the Berlin police raid.
sources: Slusser, Robert M.; Triska, Jan F. (1959). *A Calendar of Soviet Treaties, 1917–1957*. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press. p. 46.

content:
**Born:**
	* [Elizabeth Short](/wiki/Black_Dahlia "Black Dahlia"), murder victim known as "the Black Dahlia"; in [Hyde Park, Boston](/wiki/Hyde_Park,_Boston "Hyde Park, Boston"), [Massachusetts](/wiki/Massachusetts "Massachusetts") (d. 1947)
	* [Robert Horton](/wiki/Robert_Horton_(actor) "Robert Horton (actor)"), American TV actor who was the star of *[Wagon Train](/wiki/Wagon_Train "Wagon Train")* after the death of [Ward Bond](/wiki/Ward_Bond "Ward Bond"); in Los Angeles (d. 2016)
	* [Richard P. Keirn](/wiki/Richard_P._Keirn "Richard P. Keirn"), American fighter pilot and the first U.S. airman to have his plane shot by a surface-to-air missile in the Vietnam War, and one of only two Americans to be a prisoner of war in both [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") and in Vietnam; in [Akron, Ohio](/wiki/Akron,_Ohio "Akron, Ohio")

[Elizabeth Short](/wiki/Black_Dahlia "Black Dahlia"), murder victim known as "the Black Dahlia"; in [Hyde Park, Boston](/wiki/Hyde_Park,_Boston "Hyde Park, Boston"), [Massachusetts](/wiki/Massachusetts "Massachusetts") (d. 1947)

[Robert Horton](/wiki/Robert_Horton_(actor) "Robert Horton (actor)"), American TV actor who was the star of *[Wagon Train](/wiki/Wagon_Train "Wagon Train")* after the death of [Ward Bond](/wiki/Ward_Bond "Ward Bond"); in Los Angeles (d. 2016)

[Richard P. Keirn](/wiki/Richard_P._Keirn "Richard P. Keirn"), American fighter pilot and the first U.S. airman to have his plane shot by a surface-to-air missile in the Vietnam War, and one of only two Americans to be a prisoner of war in both [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") and in Vietnam; in [Akron, Ohio](/wiki/Akron,_Ohio "Akron, Ohio")
The prosecution rested in the [Leopold and Loeb](/wiki/Leopold_and_Loeb "Leopold and Loeb") trial.
sources: Hannon, Michael (May 2010). ["Leopold and Loeb Case (1924)"](https://web.archive.org/web/20140923171802/http://darrow.law.umn.edu/trialpdfs/LEOPOLD_LOEB.pdf) (PDF). *University of Minnesota Law Library*. Archived from [the original](http://darrow.law.umn.edu/trialpdfs/LEOPOLD_LOEB.pdf) (PDF) on September 23, 2014. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: The [round-the-world flyers](/wiki/First_aerial_circumnavigation "First aerial circumnavigation") reached [Kirkwall](/wiki/Kirkwall "Kirkwall") in the [Orkney Islands](/wiki/Orkney_Islands "Orkney Islands").
sources: "The U.S. Flyers". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. July 31, 1924. p. 3.

content: **Died:** [Arthur McCabe](/wiki/Arthur_McCabe "Arthur McCabe"), 37, Australian rugby player, died of a heart attack

The [Commonwealth Electoral Act 1924](/wiki/Electoral_system_of_Australia#Compulsory_voting "Electoral system of Australia"), requiring [compulsory voting](/wiki/Compulsory_voting "Compulsory voting") in Australian national elections, was given [royal assent](/wiki/Royal_assent "Royal assent") by [George V](/wiki/George_V "George V") in his capacity as [King of Australia](/wiki/King_of_Australia "King of Australia"). The law, in effect 100 years later, provides for a requirement that [enrolled voters](/wiki/Electoral_register "Electoral register") explain their absence if they fail to vote, and a fine of up to A$170 if no adequate excuse is given. The Act was sponsored after fewer than 60% of voters cast ballots in the 1922 federal election; participation increased to 91% in 1925 election.
sources: ["Odgers, Australian Senate Practice"](https://web.archive.org/web/20041231173903/http://www.aph.gov.au/SENATE/pubs/odgers/app05.htm). Aph.gov.au. Archived from [the original](http://www.aph.gov.au/senate/pubs/odgers/app05.htm) on 31 December 2004. Retrieved 29 December 2010.

content: The Allied Reparations Commission released a report estimating that Germany had only paid about half the amounts that the French, Belgians and English demanded for occupying the [Rhineland](/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Rhineland "Occupation of the Rhineland") and [Ruhr](/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Ruhr "Occupation of the Ruhr").
sources: Wales, Henry (August 1, 1924). "Cost of Allied Rhine Army Eats Up Reparations". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 4.

content: **Died:** [Cecil Holliday](/wiki/Cecil_Holliday "Cecil Holliday"), 67, British English activist in China who served as chairman of the [Shanghai Municipal Council](/wiki/Shanghai_Municipal_Council "Shanghai Municipal Council") in 1906.
